(Los socios Marlene y Juan pidieron permiso a la junta directiva por motivos de salud y no aparecen en el video)
texts.en:
Our members belong to the La Amistad Communal Bank. They live in the city of Cusco in the Cusco department. The members meet every 30 days in the Arariwa Association’s central office. In the video the governing board is verifying that the members’ documentation is correct. Our members alternate their activities between the home and selling tickets for trips, food, tires for cars, and meals. Other members offer transportation services and cell phone calling services. Fanny, 34, has to get up at dawn to take care of her two children and prepare a quinoa breakfast for the people passing by on their way to work. The member gets her family ahead. She does not have the support of her life partner. She sells breakfast on a corner from five in the morning until one in the afternoon. She has been in this business for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into her business. The member needs the loan to buy more supplies like milk and quinoa. The members need the loan to buy more products like food and tires, etc. That way they will be able to increase their business capital and have greater earnings. Then they will give their children a better quality of life. The members are grateful for and value the loan given through this medium. They promise to make their payments on time. (The members Marlene and Juan asked the governing board for permission to not appear in the video for health reasons.)

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur  LUZ MARINA from  Peru

loans.use: Buy more products like food and tires, etc.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao K. is years of age and lives in the province of Kampong Chhnang, in Cambodia. She earns a living cultivating a rice crop which she is able to plant twice a year.

Sao K. is a widow and is blessed with four children of whom two are married and the others are single. To help feed the family, her son works as a requirement worker (casual laborer).

This mature rice season, Sao K. lacks a tool for transportation her rice from her field. Therefore, she borrows a loan to buy a cow to harness to her existing cart for delivering her rice.

loans.use: To buy a cow to harness to her cart

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 46 years old, married to Grace Nyira, and they have two school-going children. He has been in the auto repair business since 2000, operating in Naivasha town. In his outdoor garage, he repairs vehicles which have a problem.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan with which he plans to buy a fully equipped toolbox.

His future plan is to build his own indoor garage to operate from instead of working from the roadside.

loans.use: To buy a new tool box for his mechanics work

loans.name: Remember To Pay Group

texts.en:
Remember To Pay is a group of five borrowers led by S. K.. He is 55 years old and is married, with six children aged 14-28 years old. S. did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty. He and his family live and work in the West Point Community, near Monrovia, Liberia.

S.’s business is the selling of building materials, such as planks and hardware. He has been running this business for 25 years and hopes to open a shop in the near future. He sells good quality planks and other materials for building in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. S. will use this loan to purchase more planks and hardware. He dreams of giving his children good medical attention when needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, S. is the one holding the sign. Tenneh Tamba is inset at lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more planks and hardware.

loans.name: Las Pioneras De Pitrufquen Group

texts.es:
Este banco comunal es llamado “Las Pioneras de Pitrufquén” y se conforma por 20 socios y socias, pertenecientes a la comuna de Pitrufquén, a 30 Km. de la ciudad de Temuco.
Ellos se dedican principalmente a negocios de artesanía en greda y tejidos, relojería, confección de buzos, peluquería, repostería y venta de carteras.
Luisa es la presidenta de este banco comunal, en la foto se encuentra a la derecha, detrás del niño y sostiene una carpeta en sus brazos. Ella tiene una peluquería en el centro de la ciudad, en donde es jefa y peluquera, negocio al cual se dedica hace 16 años. Invertirá el préstamo en tinturas, cremas, líquidos decolorantes, etc. Su sueño es tener una peluquería en su casa, para estar más cómoda. Su motivación es darle estudios superiores a su hijo de 14 años. Para ella Fondo Esperanza a significado un importante apoyo económico y educativo, menciona también lo bien que le ha hecho trabajar en el grupo al compartir sus experiencias e ideas.
Temuco es la capital de la región de la Araucanía. La ciudad se ubica a 670 kilómetros al sur de Santiago (capital de Chile) y posee una serie de balnearios lacustres y una flora y fauna nativa muy llamativas. Cabe destacar que en esta región habita el 50% de los mapuches, pueblo indígena, existente en nuestro país.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Las Pioneras de Pitrufquén” and is made up of 20 members, all of whom are residents of the Pitrufquén community, which is a 30 km from the city of Temuco. Their businesses include the sale of handicrafts like ceramics and weaving, watch repair, clothing, hair salons, pastry making, and wallet sales. Luisa is the president of this bank. In the picture, she is to the right, behind the child and with a folder in her hands. She owns a beauty salon in the center of the city and is both the manager and a hair dresser. She has had this business for 16 years. She will use her loan to buy hair dye, creams, solutions that remove color, etc. Her dream is to have a hair salon in her home, in order to be more comfortable. Her motivation comes from the desire to provide higher education to her 14-year-old son. For her, Fondo Esperanza has been an important source of economic and educational support. She also says working in a group has been good for her because she has been able to share experiences and ideas with others. Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía region. The city is located 670 kilometers to the south of Santiago, the capital of Chile, and it has a series of natural spas as well as beautiful and diverse native flora and fauna. It is also work mentioning that 50% of the country's Mapuche people, a native culture, live in this region.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise for a beauty salon: hair dye, creams, etc.

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Yean R. is a 33-year-old fish trader who sells fresh fish in a local busy market located in the capital, Phnom Penh.

R. is responsible for four teenage kids who are going to the secondary school. Also she receives income from her husband who works as a temporarily laborer in the construction sector.

R. is applying for a loan to help improve her fish-selling trade.

loans.use: To help improve her fish-selling business

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario B., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Matias B., a mason, they are blessed with seven children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Rosario has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, she is now applying for a PHP 12,000 loan as additional capital to buy groceries to replenish stocks and continue the operation of her variety store. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners meeting weekly to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to replenish stocks and continue operations of her variety store.

loans.name: Prang's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Prang U. is 62 years old and the leader of a 4-member group seeking a group loan. The group is located in Prey Phdau Cheung village in Takeo province. With the loans, all of the members hope to increase their income in order to improve their family's standard of living. Mrs. Prang U. is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field on which she cultivates rice. In addition to being a farmer, she is also a silk weaver, which earns her a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. She is asking for a loan to buy more silks to increase her business activities. Mrs. Prang U. is a widow with three children. Two are silk weavers, and the third one stays at home and also supports the mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more silks

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina was born in Namaacha, on the Mozambican border with Swaziland, 43 years ago. She studied until 4th grade but stopped because she lost her place in the school. She lives with her partner who is a school teacher. Her youngest child, aged 9, still lives with her and goes to school. She also sends money for the upbringing of her three grandchildren although they, and her older children, do not live with her. She has never left the Maputo province, just moved from the Namaacha to the Boane districts of the province. She has worked as a cleaner for the last 10 years. She works from 7.30 to 15.30 and makes 4,800 Meticais per month. Most months she is able to save. 

This is Angelina's fourth loan with Hluvuku. She wants to buy cement and iron and other materials to improve her house that she is bulding bit by bit. The previous loans were all for the same purpose. She is eager to see her housing project finished and is worried about a rise in material prices that would prevent this from happening as quickly as she would wish. Attached is a picture of her by her house that she hopes to complete with the help of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Building materials for her house

loans.name: Nueva Vida Group

texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Nuevo Vida”, and this is the second time they have a loan published on Kiva.  The members of this bank are from the city of Temuco, and they are involved in the activities of pastry-making, chocolate-making, sewing, selling cakes, frozen foods, coal, wood, and salads.
The group member interviewed was Macarena, who is the group’s president.  In the photo Macarena is in the last row, to the right, with a baby (the daughter of another group member) in her arms.
Macarena and Ingrid, another of the group members who she taught to make chocolates, make and sell the chocolates together.  They sell in various restaurants and kiosks, and in schools.
Macarena will invest this loan in materials and ingredients to make the chocolates, and in silver jewelry to expand her business.
Her dream is to have an internet café in her house or in Ingrid’s, for which they are applying for a “capital semilla” (seed capital) from a government program.
Macarena’s greatest motivation is her 5-year-old daughter – to assure a good economic future for her through her studies and everything she will need.
What Macarena likes most about Fondo Esperanza are the good moments she lives with her group and their loan officer during the group meetings, when they do their entrepreneur-training workshops and share their experiences.
Temuco is the capital of the Araucanía region. It is located 670 kilometres south of Santiago (the capital of Chile) and possesses a series of lake-side spa resorts and striking native flora and fauna. This region is also noteworthy for being the region where 50% of Chile's existing indigenous Mapuche community live; some of whom are members of Fondo Esperanza communal banks.

loans.use: Jewelry and ingredients to make chocolates

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu is married with six children, all them in school, and also takes care of some additional family members. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

Nulu owns a charcoal store in Nalukolongo market and buys charcoal from delivery vans which get it from villages. Therefore, she doesn’t incur any transport costs. She has been in this business for twenty years and works seven days a week. She also earns some money from tailoring.

Nulu rents her store in Nalukolongo and pays monthly market dues. Her customers are the local people and her neighbors. She depends on this job to get a living. Her main business challenge is the rainy season because she works from a muddy place and this hinders her customers from reaching her.

Nulu plans to use the loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She is aspiring to see her business grow big and to start going directly to villages for charcoal. She joined MCDT to get additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Samrith

texts.en:
Mrs. Samrith A. (featured in the picture), age 25, and her husband, Mr. Sopheap Phat, age 31, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married for four years and have two daughters who are currently attending school.

Samrith has been selling food in a market near a garment factory for five years. Her husband is a garment factory worker. Samrith spends a lot of money on rent each month to operate her business in the market. For this reason Samrith is asking for her first loan in the amount of $800. With this money she will purchase space in a shop, where she can operate her food selling business and avoid high rental fees.

loans.use: To buy space in a shop where she sells food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase blouses, boxer shorts, ankle braces, towels, and other products

loans.name: Kabirizi Kwetungura A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
T. Bosco, a hardworking and cooperative 38-year-old married father of four children, has been operating a goat meat and pork butchery business from Byumba trading Centre in Kihihi for over seven years. He started his business with a little capital from his previous farming business.

Bosco buys goats and pigs from the surrounding villages which he slaughters and gets ready for selling to his genuine customers who have supported him this long. His business has grown to the extent that he has been able to have his children undergo education. He reveals that, in a month, he makes 360,000 Ugandan shillings and also makes some additional income through his side business.

Bosco’s drawback is having small stock of goats and pigs in his business. Therefore, would like to use this loan to restock his business by buying more animals for his daily butcher job. His future plans are to expand his business and improve his sales revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more animals for his butchery, especially goats and pigs

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca J. is from the village of San J., Quirino. She is 60 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests a variety of vegetables to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $350 per harvest for these activities.

In 2008, Rebecca joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Rosenie

texts.en: Rosenie C. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 51 years old and is married with seven adult children. Rosenie owns and operates a business providing transportation services to local community members with her husband as the driver of the motorcycle. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Rosenie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Rosenie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Monserrate Viviana

texts.es:
Monserrate de 39 años, , tiene una tienda en la ventana delantera de su casa, vive en una zona urbana llamada Guasmo, caracterizada por la cantidad de habitantes comerciantes. 

Hace 5 atrás el comenzó a trabajar para tener su propio negocio. Con sus ahorros ella pudo comprar víveres para ubicar una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa, poco a poco construyo mejor su casa y su tienda su hijo le ayuda en la tienda cuando regresan de la escuela, ella trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 22:30pm todos los días. 

Para seguir con su negocio el quiere con el préstamo comprar perfumes, arroz, bebidas, azúcar. En el futuro quiere que su hijo tenga una mejor vida y surtir su tienda con mas productos.
texts.en:
Monserrate is 39 years old and operates a store from the front window of her home. She lives in an urban area called Guasmo, characterized by the number of merchants operating from home. Five years ago she began working towards having her own business and with her savings she was able to purchase merchandise to set up a store in the front part of her home. Little by little she has been able to make improvemetns to her home and the store. Her son helps her with the store when he is home from school. She works from 6AM until 10:30PM everyday and to continue on with the business she is asking for this loan to purchase perfumes, rice, beverages, and sugar. She wants to stock her store with more products and for her child to have a better life in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Gustavo Gutierrez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Perfumes, rice and lotions.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “MUJERES UNIDAS ”;  El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de  San Sebastián, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Juana;   ella tiene 34 años de edad, es conviviente; y tiene 2 hijos,  La socia se dedica a la compra y venta de cosméticos por catálogos, ella vende 2 diferentes líneas de cosméticos por catálogos, ella se vale de sus amigas y conocidas para llevar sus catálogos y ofrecer los diferentes productos, ella lleva vendiendo desde hace 3 años, La socia ayuda con este ingreso apagar los servicios de la casa y a apoyar con la comida, ella desea una buena educación para sus menores hijos y por esto trata de ser la número uno en ventas. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de ofertas para incrementar sus ganancias.

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This borrower is part of the Mujeres Unidas communal bank. The bank is located in the district of San Sebastián, which is in the province and department of Cusco.

Juana is 34 years old and has a live-in partner and two children. She works buying and selling two different cosmetics lines by catalog and visits her friends and acquaintances to bring her catalogs and sell the different products. She has been in this business for the past three years. With her earnings, Juana helps to pay for the household utilities and to contribute to the food. She wants her young children to have a good education, which is why she tries to be #1 in sales. She is requesting the loan to invest in the purchase of items on sale to increase her earnings.

She appreciates and values the loan provided and she promises to make her loan payments according to the established time frame.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of items on sale to increase her earnings.

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Abra reste une femme très dynamique, malgré son âge avancé, elle continue d’exercer comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail  de produits génériques, elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé et sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. Voulant agrandir son stock elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat d’1 carton de vitamine, 1 carton de paracétamol, 1 carton de déparasitant et divers autres produits génériques. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Ce crédit qu’elle sollicite est son deuxième après remboursement du premier
texts.en: In spite of her advanced age, Abra is a very energetic woman.  She continues to operate an income-generating business in the retail sale of generic products.  She gets her supplies at Lome's large market.   Her clientele consists of all types of people. Wanting to expand her stock, she is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy one carton of vitamins, 1 box of paracetamol, 1 carton of deworming medication and other generic products. She is married and the mother of two children. The loan she is requesting is her seond; the first loan has been repaid.

loans.use: Purchase of generic products

loans.name: María Emérita

texts.es:
María Emérita tiene 24 años de edad, es soltera y no cuenta con hijos dependientes, vive junto a sus padres el el caserío La Colorada del distrito de Mórrope, una zona agrícola que se encuentra ubicada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales menores. Ella cría sus animales en un ambiente ubicado dentro de su vivienda y los vende a sus vecinos y a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona en donde reside. Los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad los utiliza solventar sus gastos personales y ayudar a sus padres con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia. 

María desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más animales y alimento balanceado, de modo que pueda ampliar sus ventas y percibir mayores ganancias. Asimismo desea realizar algunas mejoras en sus corrales. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.

María es una mujer empeñosa y con muchas ganas de salir adelante. Ella planea trabajar arduamente para seguir colaborando con el desarrollo de su familia.
texts.en:
María Emérita is 24 years old.  She is single and has no dependent children.  She lives with her parents in the village of La Colorada in the district of Mórrope, an agricultural region which is located in the province of Lambayeque, more than an hour from the city of Chiclayo.

She raises and sells young animals.  She raises her animals on her property and sells them to neighbors and dealers who usually visit the area where she lives.  The income that she makes from this activity is used to cover her personal expenses and to help her parents in supporting the family financially.

María would like to expand her business with the purchase of more animals and balanced feed so that she can increase her sales and make more profit.  She would also like to make some improvements in her pens.  This is why she has made her first loan request from Edpyme Alternativa for 2,000 nuevos soles.

María is a determined woman who has a great desire to get ahead.  She plans to work hard in order to continue contributing to the development of her family.

loans.use: To buy animals and balanced feed in order to expand her business of raising and selling animals

loans.name: Silvia Dinora

texts.es: Silvia Dinora R. de 44 años de edad, es una persona muy humilde y responsable, quien desea mucho poder contar con una vida mejor para ella y su familia. Silvia vive junto a su esposo, y junto a dos hijos. Ella trabaja arduamente en su hogar, haciendo y vendiendo tortillas, así mismo posee una venta ropa para mujeres y niños, la cual comercializa en su casa y de forma ambulante.  Silvia solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de maíz, así mismo comprar una reserva de cilindros de gas propano. De esta misma manera ella desea poder comprar mayor cantidad de ropa, y así aprovechar esta temporada navideña, Debido a que el sueldo de su esposo es bastante bajo, ella debe buscar la manera de poder obtener mayores ganancias, lo cual beneficie en gran manera a sus hijos, los cuales son la inspiración para que ella se esfuerce más y más por lograr sus metas de poder mejorar su negocio, todo con vista en el presente y futuro de sus hijos y de su hogar.
texts.en:
Silvia Dinora R., 44, is a very humble, responsible person who very much wants to have a better life for herself and her family.  She lives with her husband and two children.  She works hard at home making tortillas.  She also sells women’s and children’s clothing from home and as a street vendor.

She is asking for a loan to buy larger amounts of corn as well as a reserve stock of propane gas tanks.  She’d also like to buy a larger quantity of clothes to take advantage of the Christmas season.

Because her husband’s salary is quite low she looks for ways to earn higher profits for better benefit of her children who are the inspiration for her to try even harder every day to reach her goals of improving her business all with the present and future goal in mind of her children and her home.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell and corn to make tortillas.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan P., 42, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated city in the country. P. raises ducks, earning an income of about USD 8 per day. His wife grows morning glories to sell, earning an income of USD 5 per day. P. has to spend USD 75 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase duck food. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy animal food to raise ducks

location.town: Mean Chey District, Phnom Penh City

loans.name: Sipriana

texts.es:
Doña Sipriana de 55 años de edad, vive junto a su Esposo Lino Amador y sus hijos en Colonia Puerto Principe de Nueva Guinea, su principal actividad es la ganaderia, donde ha crecido por tanto conoce bien el manejo de su hato Ganadero siendo esta la principal fuente de ingresos, ya que realiza venta de leche y comercializa  ternero de Engorde,  es una mujer con principios, responsable y enprendedora, lucha con su Familia para obtener comodida y sobre todo salud.  

Solicita su crédito a Kiva para realizar compra de ternero desarrollo, asi aumentar su inventario ganadero y a la vez obtener mayor ingresos.  

Su sueño es que sus Hijos manejen bien su Capital y que gocen de buena salud que no les falte el pan de cada dia.
texts.en:
Sipriana is 55 years old.  She lives together with her husband, Lino Amador, and her children in the Puerto Principe subdivision of Nueva Guinea.  Her main business activity is livestock farming.  She has grown in her business and knows very well how to manage her herd of cattle.  This is her main source of income.  She sells milk and calves for fattening.  She is a principled, responsible and enterprising woman who works hard with her family to obtain comfort and, above all, good health.

She is requesting a Kiva loan to buy a growing calf so that she can increase her livestock inventory and make more profits.

Sipriana's dream is for her children to manage their capital well, for them to enjoy good health and for them never to go hungry.

loans.use: To buy a growing calf

loans.name: María Angelita

texts.es:
La Señora María L. es socia del banco comunal 12 de Abril, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por la belleza de su naturaleza, cuenta con su centro histórico el mismo que en diciembre de 1999 fue nombrado patrimonio cultural de la humanidad, su gente mantiene sus tradiciones y cultura.

Nuestra socia tiene 60 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos de 38 y 32 años  que son casados y viven independientes. Con su trabajo ha logrado comprar una casa la misma que se encuentra pagando y esta feliz por ello.

Doña María es negociante de frutas y verduras, esta actividad la realiza hace 15 años y cuenta con su propio puesto en el mercado, trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde.

Este es su primer crédito y fue invitada por una amiga, su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más frutas y verduras para su negocio. Su meta es crecer mucho más en su negocio.
texts.en:
Ms María L. is a member of the 12 de Abril (April 12) Communal Bank. She lives in the city of Cuenca, a town renowned for the beauty of its nature. Its historical center was nominated Word Heritage Site in December 1999, and its inhabitants preserve their traditions and culture.

María is 60 years old, she is a single mother of two children aged 38 and 32, who are married and live independently. Thanks to her job she has succeeded in buying a house she is still paying for, and she is happy about it.

Maria is a saleswoman: she has been selling fruits and vegetables for 15 years, and she has her own stand in the market; she works from Sunday to Sunday from 6 in the morning to 6 at night.

This is her first loan; she has been invited by a friend and she will use the loan to buy more fruits and vegetables for her shop. Her goal is for her activity to grow even more.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Norn P., 26, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for the most populate city in the country. She sells groceries, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a blacksmith earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 105 on food, 15 on the children’s education, and USD 45 on other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to purchase more groceries to expand her business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

location.town: Mean Chey District, Phnom Penh City

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty F. is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Elesio F., who is 49 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business.  

They have two children who are 11 and 26 years old. 

Betty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Betty has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her third cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her family's future and her children’s education. 

Betty is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Genelie

texts.en:
Genelie Q. is from the village of Jampason, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Genelie is married. To make a living, Genelie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Genelie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Genelie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genelie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Genelie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & beverages. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Genelie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for sale such as canned goods & beverages

loans.name: Dioleta

texts.en:
Dioleta is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a ready-to-wear clothes/pants business and a fish vending business. She lives in the municipality of Sta. Fe, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Dioleta is borrowing PHP 29,500 to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Dioleta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and pants for resale

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
Pablita O. is from the village of Pandan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Pablita is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Pablita provides motorela or habal-habal transport services to local community members. Pablita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Pablita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed to maintain service. 

Pablita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional tools needed to maintain her vehicle. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed maintain her transport service vehicle

loans.name: Saleh

texts.ar: صالح في عمر 31 سنة متزوج وله ولد يعمل سائق سيارة أجرة له في عمله 8 سنوات يريد دائما تطوير عمله وعائلته ماديا واجتماعيا يسعى الى امتلاك سيارة تاكسي ثانية لكن ما يمنعه هي المادة يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى صيانة الموتير وتجديد التأمين والميكانيك الخاص بالسيارة لا يواجه صعوبة في عمله سوى الصعوبة المادية يتلقى دائما الدعم من افراد عائلته ومحيطه ويساعد نفسه على تخطي المصاعب من خلال زيادة مدخوله في المواسم السياحية
texts.en: Saleh is 31 years old and married with a son. He works as a taxi driver and has been doing this for 8 years. He is always seeking to develop his business and improve his family's social and financial position. He wants to own a second car but shortage of funds is preventing him from this. With this loan he wants to perform maintenance and mechanical work on his car. He does not face any difficulty other than lack of financial support. He has the full support of his family and those around him and is trying to take the necessary steps to increase his income during the tourist season.

loans.use: to perform maintenance and mechanical work on his taxi.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old Lebanese single man living with his parents and one sibling. He has worked in multiple restaurants and snack bars for more than 20 years.  This acquisition of experience permitted him to open his own snack bar in 2001. He started serving customers yummy sandwiches and subs such as fajitas, chicken, and beef.  

Recently, he transformed his snack bar into a diner and began to offer customers appetizers, salads, and platters. He helps his father with the household expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase supplementary food and other products. He is confident that he will always consider the demand of his customers and hopes that the loan will positively impact his business.

loans.use: to purchase supplementary food and other products.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth A. is from the village of West Kibawe, Kibawe, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Janeth is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Janeth owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling junk foods, candies, ready to wear clothing, sandals & slippers in the local community. Janeth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Janeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used towards working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Janeth is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock of sandals & slippers. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Janeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory of sandals & slippers.

loans.name: Lucia M

texts.en:
Lucia is 46.  She is married and has two children, ages nine and four. She has two other dependents living with her because her friends gave them to her.  

In 2007, Lucia established her cosmetics and artificial hair business.  She started the business because she wanted to help her husband provide a livelihood for their family.  Lucia works six days a week and eight hours a day, and she earns about Le 1,000,000 every month.  

Lucia would like a loan of Le 5,000,000.  She has successfully repaid four previous loans in the group loan format, and now she needs a new loan to buy more cosmetics and artificial hair.  She hopes this loan will increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000.  In the future, Lucia plans to get a bigger shop so she can attract more customers and buy a piece of land.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and artificial hair for her business

loans.name: Judith Del Carmen

texts.es:
Judith tiene su negocio propio, vende pizza y queque el cual elabora ella misma, teniendo siete años en el negocio, en donde tiene materia prima para la elaboración que es la harina. Con este trabajo ha podido suplir las necesidades de su familia, ya que solo con el trabajo de su esposo no se ajusta siendo distribuidor de productos en una empresa privada.
Atreves de Afodenic ha venido haciendo mejoras a su casa, como su inversión, siendo el octavo crédito en donde invertirá en la compra de materiales de construcción como: losetas, y poste de cemento, cemento, arena,  para hacer un muro en forma de U,  en donde espera reguardar su propiedad como su familia, que solo por este medio se le ha hecho posible esta mejoras a su casa.
texts.en:
Judith has her own business; she sells pizza and cake that she herself makes.  She’s been in business 7 years.  Her main raw material is flour.  This business has allowed her to meet her family’s basic needs because her husband’s earnings as a delivery man for a private firm are just not enough.

She’s been investing Afodenic funds in home improvements.  This will be the eighth loan that she’ll use to buy building materials and supplies like tile, cement posts, cement and sand to erect a U-shaped wall to safeguard her property and her family.  It’s been solely through this means that she’s been able to make these home improvements possible.

loans.use: to buy building materials to erect a wall.

loans.name: Angela María

texts.es:
En la localidad conocida con el nombre de Pachinche  de la parroquia Colon de la ciudad de Portoviejo lugar conocido por su gente trabajadora y dedicada a la agricultura y la ganadería cada quince días se reúnen los socios del Banco Comunal Damas Emprendedoras De Pachinche.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Angela, tiene 32 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 15, 14 y 8 años de edad, los dos mayores estudian  en colegio y el menor en escuela. Su esposo es bodeguero de una empresa en la ciudad de Manta.

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de productos de Yanbal y Esika (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Además de esto también se dedica a realizar trabajos de bordados, nos cuenta que estos trabajos los hace a base de pedidos ya que una señora de la ciudad de Chone cada quince días llega a hasta su casa a comprarle lo que ella ha elaborado hasta la fecha y le deja más modelos y encargos para la próxima quincena, lleva tres años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien ya que este es un trabajo que lo hace en los momentos que está desocupa, las ventas de los productos Yanbal y Esika lo hace dos días a la semana y estas ventas son puerta a puerta.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, bisutería, y materia prima para los bordados como telas e hilos. Esta en el banco comunal desde el inicio y es la presidenta del mismo.
 
Su sueño es tener una microempresa de tejido.
texts.en:
The members of the Damas Emprendedoras de Pachinche Communal Bank meet every fifteen days in the town of Pachinche in the parish of Colon, city of Portoviejo.  The town is known for its hard-working people who are dedicated to agriculture and livestock farming.   

In this town, we meet Angela.  She is 32 years old.  She is married and has 3 children, ages 15, 14 and 8.  The two oldest are high school students and the youngest is in elementary school.  Her husband is a winemaker in a company in the city of Manta.  

She is a housewife and, in order to earn her own income, she sells Yanbal and Esika (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume, and ladies’ accessories).  In addition, she does embroidery.  She tells us that she does these jobs on order as a woman from the city of Chone comes to her house every fifteen days to buy what she has made to date.  She leaves her more models and orders for the next fifteen days.  She has been involved in this activity for 3 years and it is going very well as she can do this work during her free time.  She sells her Yanbal and Esika products door to door two days a week.

She will use this loan to buy perfume, creams, costume jewelry, and raw materials for the embroidery such as fabric and thread.  She has been a member of this bank since the start and she is the president.  Her dream is to have a micro-business selling fabric.

loans.use: to buy perfume, creams, costume jewelry, fabric, and thread.

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is 54 years old, married and has five sons. All of her sons are young. Her eldest son sells clothes. Her second son is a rickshaw driver and her third son operates a clothes selling business too. Yasmeen herself is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighborhood clients. She has been operating her business for many years and is well known among her clients for her good quality work. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her second son. With the loan, he will buy a new body for his rickshaw and do some repair works so it works smoothly and attracts many passengers to get service from him due to his well-conditioned rickshaw.  
He has been operating his transport business for the past eight years and Yasmeen is hopeful that after the loan investment, his business will grow better and his income will increase. Yasmeen is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Yasmeen.

loans.use: To repair and buy a new rickshaw body

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina is 48 years old and lives in Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and a mother of seven school-age dependents.

Angelina works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. Each month she earn approximately PHP 5,600 in this work. She has requested a loan of PHP 7,500 at GDMPC to purchase fishing nets.

Angelina has been a member of GDMPC for two years. In the future, Angelina hopes to gain more profit from fishing and own an additional fishing boat.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: United Brothers Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very please to present to you members of the “United Brothers” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of SLL 800,000, for each, in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Salieu is the leader of this group. Salieu is 29-years old and married. He has 2 children, 1 of whom is attending primary school. Salieu sells mobile phone accessories and has been running this business for 5 years now. With his share of this loan he is going to buy mobile phone accessories in large quantities to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone accessories in large quantities to add to his business.

loans.name: Nabeela

texts.en: Nabeela is a 35-year-old young woman. She is married and has three sons and three daughters. Nabeela lives in Gaza city, Gaza Strip in Palestine. Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a decent salary. Nabeela wants to make some repairs for the public transportation taxi her husband drives after his working hours, which helps to get additional income for the family. She doesn't have enough cash to pay for it. Therefore she took out a loan of amount $2,000. FATEN's loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, will enable Nabeela to pay easily for repairing the taxi that will make it work more efficient and generate more income for the family. Nabeela is a religious conservative woman. Therefore, her husband is photographed instead.

loans.use: To make taxi repairs and maintenance

loans.name: Minh

texts.en:
Minh is a 48-year-old married woman with two daughters. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. For the past 24 years, she and her husband have run a food stall to cover all family living expenses and their children's education fees. The business is going smoothly and she would like a loan to buy new furniture, bowls and chopticks and better quality food and beverages to provide to her customers.

She hopes this will increase her income, help her to improve her living conditions and allow her to set aside some savings.

loans.use: To buy new furniture and better quality food and beverages for her food stall.

loans.name: Kuguta Kushanda Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 50-year-old Marcy from Norton, about 40km from Harare. She is married, with four children ages 18, 20, 23 and 29. Three of her children are attending school. She also cares for three dependents. Marcy has been running a poultry business for 16 years. She says the main challenge she faces is bird flu which attacked the chickens during winter. Marcy has requested a loan of $300 to add layers to her stock. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to send her children to good schools. In the future, Marcy plans to increase the number of chickens she sells to get better profits.

loans.use: To buy more chicks for her poultry business

loans.name: Mariana De Jesús

texts.es:
La Señora. Mariana es socia del banco comunal Fe y Alegría, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por la belleza de sus calles, su estructura arquitectónica que se mezcla entre lo colonial y lo moderno, la variedad en su gastronomía cautiva el paladar de propios y extraños, su gente es amable y mantienen la cultura de sus ancestros.
 
Doña Mariana tiene 62 años, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido  7 hijos quienes son mayores de edad, 5 de ellos son casados e independientes y sus 2 hijos solteros trabajan y le ayudan económicamente. Su esposo labora en la agricultura, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. 

La Señora Mariana es de profesión auxiliar de enfermería, lleva 15 años en el trabajo y tiene horarios rotativos. También se dedica a la costura hace 20 años y realiza todo tipo de arreglo en prendas de vestir.
 
En el banco comunal se encuentra en su cuarto crédito y su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de tela para seguir con su negocio. 

Su sueño es de tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Mariana is a member of Fe y Alegría [Faith and Joy] community bank. She lives in Cuenca, a city known for the beauty of its streets, an architectural style that mixes the colonial with the modern, and the gastronomical variety that delights the palates of both locals and visitors. The people of Cuenca are friendly and maintain the culture of their ancestors. 

Mariana is 62 years old, married, and her marriage has produced seven children, now adults; five of them are married and independent, and her two single children work and help her financially. Her husband works in agriculture. As they rent, they do not have their own house. 

By profession Mariana is a nurse's aide, which she's done for 15 years, and works a rotating schedule. For 20 years she has also been a seamstress and does all types of repairs on clothing. 

This is her fourth loan with the community bank, and she will use the loan to buy fabric for use in her business. 

Her dream is to have her own house.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 19 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Arlene has a retail shop that sells clothing & beauty products from AVON & NATASHA. She has had this business for one year. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy clothing products from AVON & NATASHA to sell.

Arlene is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Arlene hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing products from AVON & NATASHA to sell

loans.name: Umurimo Group

texts.fr:
Jean Bosco fait partie du groupe Umurimo. Le nom du groupe signifie « le travail ». Il a 31 ans et il est marié avec 2 enfants de 1 à 3 ans. Son niveau d’éducation est  6 ans de primaire.

Jean Bosco est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de faire la semence sélectionner du riz et utilisation des fertilisants pour augmenter la récolte. Dans les prochaines années, Jean Bosco voudrait être parmi les meilleurs cultivateurs, vendeurs  de riz dans sa région et acheter d’autres champs. Avec les profits, il prévoit de prendre soins de sa famille et payer le minerval de son petit frère.
texts.en:
Jean Bosco is a member of the group Umurimo. The name of the group means "work". He is 31 and married with two children, one and three years old. His educational level is 6 years of primary school. 

Jean Bosco is a rice grower. This is his first loan with ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy chemical fertilizer for his rice farming. 

His strategy for growing his business is to sow select rice seed and use fertilizers to increase his harvest. In the coming years, Jean Bosco would like to be among the best farmers and sellers of rice in his region and also would like to buy other fields. With the profit, he intends to take care of his family and pay school fees for his younger brother.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizer for his rice farming.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 23 years.  She is 47 years old and a mother to four children, all of whom are in school.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of the existing clients. This will be her second loan.  She paid all her previous loan well and on time.  She plans to use the loan to buy farming materials: seeds, fertilizers, and sprays.

In the future, Cecilia hopes to improve her farming skills and become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy farming materials: seeds, fertilizers, and sprays.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine is a 47-year-old married woman with six children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in firewood for four years. She started with a few customers in the area and now supplies to a primary school. Her vision is to have a wholesale shop plus educating her children. Justine needs the loan to pay school fees.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Karypjan's Group

texts.en:
Karypjan is the leader of this group. She is a resident of a small village called Bokonbaevo, which is located in the Isykul region in the northeast part of Kyrgyzstan. She is 50 and married to a farmer. 

Five years ago, with an initial investment of 3,000 KGS, the family started to breed livestock. They started this business because of the need for funds to meet the family’s daily needs. By reselling livestock after fattening, Karypjan earns about 5,000 KGS per month. 

With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase hay to feed the livestock during the winter season. In the future she wishes to see her son  wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay.

loans.name: Duong

texts.en:
Duong is 70 years old. He has three children: two sons and one daughter. He lives with his family in Ho Chi Minh City. He earns a living running a general store, which he has done for 20 years. 

Duong would like to take a loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic goods, such as foods and beverages, to stock his general store. He hopes this will enable him to better meet the needs of his customers and increase the turnover of his business. He also hopes that through the loan, his business will generate a higher income and will help him to improve his family's living conditions and enable him to set aside some savings.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic goods, such as foods and beverages, to stock his general store

loans.name: Virginia De Jesus

texts.es:
La señora Virginia tiene 34 años D. edad, es casada con tres hijos.

Ella tiene 18 años D. dedicarse al comercio D. productos D. la canasta básica, desD. que se caso se ha dedicado e esta actividad. Virginia realiza sus compras en una ciudad del oriente del país que esta a treinta y cinco minutos del lugar donD. vive. 

El préstamo que solicita a Fundación Campo, es para comprar granos básicos para la venta y para comprar ropa para venderla en el mes D. diciembre. D. esta manera ella tendrá variedad D. productos para ofrecer a sus clientes y así recibirá mayores ingresos que le permitirá mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia. Ella espera que su tienda crezca, para ahorrar y hacerle algunas mejoras a su casa y brindarle el estudio universitario a su hija mayor.
texts.en:
Viriginia is 34 years old, she is married and she has three children.

She has been engaged in selling basic necessities for 18 years; she started working in  this activity since she got married. Viriginia buys her products in a town in the east of the country that is located thirty-five minutes away from where she lives.

The loan she is requesting to Fundación Campo will be used to buy basic grains to sell and to buy clothes she will sell in December. In this way she will have a variety of products to offer to her customers, her income will consequently increase and this will allow her to improve her family’s standard of living. She hopes for her activity to grow, in order to be able to save some money to be used to make improvements to her house and to pay for university education for her eldest daughter.

loans.use: To buy basic grains and clothes to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 41 years old.  She is married and has 7 children.   

Juliet works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 16000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell.  She has been running the sari-sari store for 5 years and also earns an income from a boarding house.


Juliet has borrowed and paid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan.  She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: buy additional stocks to sell

loans.name: El Progreso Group

texts.es:
El comite lleva por nombre El Progreso, debido a que el comite fue progresando con la fundacion, han asumido el compromiso de mantener unido el grupo y trabajar bajo un marco de responsabilidad, actualmente se encuentran en el sexto ciclo, integrado por 12 mujeres quienes invierten sus prestamos en sus respectivas actividades.
Una de esas mujeres es la señora Julia, quien nos cuenta que se dedica a la venta de empanadas. Cuenta que siempre tiene mucha venta, lo cual la ayuda a tener mejores ingresos con lo que ayuda a su familia. Ella dice que uno de sus sueños es poder tener una casilla donde vender los productos que tiene.
Solicita la ayuda de la fundación y de kiva para poder comprar carnes, pollo, jamón y queso, huevo y condimentos, los cuales son indispensables para su negocio.
texts.en:
The committee goes by the name of El Progreso [Progress] due to the fact that the committee was making progress with the foundation. They have pledged to remain a united group and to work responsibly. They are currently in their sixth loan cycle. The members are made up of 12 women who invest their loans in their respective activities.

One of these women is Señora Julia who tells us that she sells empanadas for a living. She says that her sales are always high and this helps her to have a better income which supports her family. She says that one of her dreams is to have a stall where she can sell her products.

She is requesting help from the foundation and from kiva to purchase meat, chicken, ham and cheese, eggs and condiments which are essential to her business.

loans.use: to buy meat, chicken, ham and cheese, eggs and condiments.

loans.name: Liliana Maria

texts.es: La señora Liliana María a sus 35 años se dedica a la fotografía desde hace dos años, cuando montó en su casa su estudio fotográfico. Desde entonces a captado una gran cantidad de clientes gracias su trabajo de buena calidad, con lo que ha podido aportar a los gastos del hogar donde convive con su esposo y sus dos hijos. Con el objetivo de incrementar la capacidad de su negocio y poder atender así más clientes en su estudio fotográfico, la señora Liliana María requiere de la compra de luces para su estudio fotográfico.
texts.en: Liliana Maria, 35, began been working as a photographer 2 years ago, when she set up a photography studio in her house.  Since then, she has attracted a large number of customers thanks to the good quality of her work.  With this business, she has been able to contribute to the household expenses, where she lives with her husband and their two children.  Liliana Maria needs to buy lights for her studio; this will increase her ability to work and will allow her to provide better service to her customers.

loans.use: to buy lights for her photography studio

loans.name: Ajoh

texts.en: Ajoh is 28 years old and married with no children. She has had a business selling charcoal in Bor, South Sudan for three years. Ajoh is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mon, 29, is married and resides with his wife and one child in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. He has been working as a construction worker for over three years, earning approximately USD 3 per day. His wife is a garment worker who earns about USD 3 per day. 

Due to lack of funds, Mon is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase construction materials to build his house. This money will help him finish his house construction and provide better living conditions for his family. 

In the future, he plans to send his child to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build his house

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Hello Kiva Lenders, meet Cynthia, a first born in a family of two. She was raised in Western Kenya, Mumias. She lost her mother in 2009 when she was in form four, unfortunately, her dad lost his job the same year. Cynthia says their lives turned around and she was forced to move to Nairobi to live with her aunt in Kibera slums. Her aunt owns a secondhand clothes stall in Kibera at Toy market but her job doesn’t fetch her enough money to support her family of seven plus Cynthia. As result, she wasted 5 years at home because she couldn’t raise college fees. Later on, in 2014, she lost her only brother 
Cynthia joined Digital Divide Data in the year 2014. She is looking forward to joining Kenyatta University in January 2016 to pursue Bachelor of Commerce if given a chance. For her to do this, she needs a loan of $500. Her dream has always been to be an accountant and she believes this opportunity will enable her achieve her career dreams and make an impact to her family and community since she come from a community where girl child education is undervalued.
Since joining DDD, she caters for her personal needs and supports her sick dad too.  As a Data Management Operator, she has earned several skills such us, leadership, computer skills, interpersonal and communication skills. Her hobbies are travelling, cooking, and reading inspirational books.

loans.use: TO PAY FOR UNIVERSITY TUITION FEES

loans.name: Salimata

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the members of the Katakal women’s association, represented by Salimata D.. The Katakal group describes their business activities:

“The Katakal association is a group of women from the village of Siganar. The village has over 3,000 inhabitants, which is why an agriculture project is a good choice for helping the women to profit from the potentials of this region, from which they have earned income for over ten years. The purpose of our group is to improve the living conditions of our members and increase their income. The business activities planned by our group are:

• Agriculture: This is based on gardening, where the needs are: inputs (seeds, fertilizer, phytosanitary products), and equipment (watering cans, rakes, hoes, pitchforks, etc.)

• Commerce: This is the principal business activity of the group; the women take local products [i.e. fresh produce from their gardens, and perhaps handicrafts such as pottery or mats woven from palm fronds, etc.] produced by the members of the group and market them throughout the region of Ziguinchor. They also make preserves out of fruits and vegetables.”

Original French:

“Contexte du Projet : Le groupement Katakal est un groupement de femmes du village de Siganar Sa population compte plus de 3000habitants et c’est pourquoi un projet d’agriculture viendra au point pour aider les femmes à exploiter les potentiels du milieu qu’elles exploitent depuis plus de 10 ans.

Objectifs du Prêt : l’objectif visé par le groupement est :

- D’améliorer les conditions de vie des membres du groupement et d’augmenter leur revenus.

Activités : Les activités que se propose le groupement sont :

- L’agriculture : elle est basée sur le maraîchage ou les besoins sont : les intrants (semences engrais, produits phytosanitaire), et le petit matériel (arrosoirs, râteaux, pèles, houes, brouettes fourches etc.…)

- Le commerce : Il est le principal activité du groupement ; de par les produits locaux produits par les membres du groupement qui assure elles même la commercialisation de leurs produits au niveau de toute la région de Ziguinchor, elles font aussi la transformation des fruits et légumes. »

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of fruit and vegetable seeds, fertilizer, rakes, watering cans, hoes, and equipment for making fruit and vegetable preserves; transportation of fresh produce and preserves to market

loans.name: Kurbonjon

texts.en: Kurbonjon has 6 years of experience in trade. She is married and has two sons. The whole family lives with her parents-in-law. They were the ones who suggested to Kurbonjon to start her own business. They assured her that they will take care of thechildren while she is at work. Her husband works as a driver in a big company producing jeans. Currently Kurbonjon works on her own and after receiving the loan she would like to open one more location for trade. She will hire an employee to help her with that. This second location will be placed at the big open-air market on Fridays and Sundays. She has already chosen the place and submitted the necessary documents to the market administration for it. She has to pay $30 per month as rent  for this place and the rest of the money she will spend to buy goods.

loans.use: Opening a second location for trade

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Miss Hong is 38 years old and her husband is 39 of ages. They have 3 children between 16 and 7 who are going to school. They have 6000 square meters of rice land. Mr Huong, her husband works on their paddy-field. In addition, Huong works as daily laborer but the work can not find easily. Last year, Miss Hong failed her past investment because the pigs she was raising got sick, still she repaid her loan. So making girdle cake is thus important for their family to increase income by $ 1,5/person/month. Average income is $ 8/person/month.

loans.use: marking girdle cake business

loans.name: Oralia

texts.es:
Oralia is married and she has two children. Her husband is retired and the retirement pension that he receives is very little and insufficient to cover the basic needs of his family, so Oralia started selling of shoes three years ago in search of obtaining an extra income that would allow her family improve the quality of life. Fortunately, her liking for sales and her character make it easy for Oralia to relate to others, this has helped her to increase her clients' portfolio and sales.

In these moments Oralia is requesting a loan of $475 that she will use to buy merchandise to be able to cover the demand of her clients and improve her service. She promises to repay the loan in 4 months. Be an important part in Oralia's life and her family by helping in the growth of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ana GabrieL. Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Oralia es casada y tiene dos hijos, su esposo es jubilado y L. pensión que recibe es muy poca e insuficiente para cubrir las necesidades básicas D. su familia, por lo que hace tres años Oralia inició con L. venta D. zapatos en busca D. obtener un ingreso extra que le permitiera mejorar L. calidad D. vida D. su familia. Afortunadamente su gusto por las ventas y su carácter que le facilita el relacionarse con los demás le ha ayudado a incrementar su cartera D. clientes y sus ventas.

En estos momentos Oralia está solicitando un préstamo D. $ 475 dólares que empleará en L. compra D. mercancía para poder cubrir L. demanda D. sus clientes y mejorar el servicio que ofrece, elL. ofrece devolver esta cantidad en 4 meses. Se parte importante en L. vida D. Oralia y su familia, contribuyendo al crecimiento D. su negocio.

Translated from Spanish by Ana GabrieL. Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Buy Merchandise

loans.name: Maofa

texts.en: Maofa T. is twenty-seven years of age from the village of Fagalii-uta.  She’s married and has three children.  They both work so hard to develop their family, but since the S.P.B.D has introduced this programme, everything is much easier for her and her family.  Her business is a plantation; she works from the morning until the evening.  Her husband helps her out by weeding the unwanted grass, planting more foods such as taro, banana, yams, etc., and taking the products to sell at the market.  She earns more than two hundred tala a week from their selling.  She will use her loan to buy equipment to help her run their business and maintain its good condition.

loans.use: To purchase planting equipment and supplies

loans.name: Teodolinda

texts.es:
Teodolinda, in addition to working and maintaining a home, is also studying at the university to become an English teacher. She lives with her husband and two children, the oldest an engineering student at the university and the youngest is also in school. She started selling in the market, but due to location problems she ended up setting up her business on the patio of her home. Her customers quickly became aware of the great flavor and variety of the foods that she prepares. She counts on the assistance of her children, who help her with purchases of ingredients and serving customers. Her husband, a teacher, also helps out – making the success of the business a family affair! Because she is located in a high-traffic area, it is necessary to improve her location with a tarp/cover to make her customers more comfortable and sheltered from the strong sun. She asks for a loan to assist her in meeting this goal. Improving her business and earnings prospects in this way will also help her finish her studies and to continue working to improve her family’s quality of life. They would all be very grateful for this opportunity.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Teodolinda a pesar de trabajar y mantener su hogar estudia en la universidad para ser profesora de inglés, vive con su esposo y sus dos queridos hijos, el mayor estudia en la universidad la carrera de ingeniería de sistemas y el hijo menor está en el colegio; ella empezó vendiendo en el mercado debido al problema de la reubicación por el que atravesaron muchas personas tuvo la premura de buscar un local y sin dudar acondicionó el patio de su casa, de esta manera en forma rápida se hizo de clientes debido al buen sabor y a la gran variedad de platos que ofrece; cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos en la compra de insumos y la atención al público, así como de su esposo que es profesor, quién comparte su tiempo para ayudar y compartir los gastos familiares.A razón de que está en una zona transitada y por estar frente a la plaza del distrito es que su negocio empezó a tener la necesidad de ser acondicionado con una carpa por el fuerte sol y para comodidad de los clientes que gustan del buen sabor de Teodolinda.Solicita un préstamo para llevar adelante su objetivo; así mismo este hecho le permitirá concluir su carrera de maestra, continuar trabajando y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia quienes desde ya se encuentran muy contentos por vuestra ayuda.

loans.use: Purchase tent/tarp and ingredients for food sales.

loans.name: Rosnani

texts.en: Rosnani is 29 years old and is a mother of child aged 13. She sells clothes on credit by going door to door. She usually earns US$7 per day. Her husband, A., is a driver who earns US$2 per day so she has to work hard to cover their daily needs. She requests a US$100 loan to expand her inventory to serve more customers, thereby earning more income for her child's education. Rosnani is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Akhmadova

texts.en: Akhmadova T. is a 47-year-old woman who owns a small livestock business in a southern village in Saatli. She is married and has four children.
